There is a long list of musical instruments that aren't what a Victorian aunt would call 'ladylike'. They need sturdy bicep strength and lots of lung power. But one by one, the manly tabla, ghatam, mridangam, shehnai, and the unwieldy rudra veena have all been mastered by women. There was one instrument that stayed stubbornly hyper-macho ‚Äî the saxophone. The only time you saw a woman with a sax in India was in ads and movies. Till the sax sisters from Mangalore, MS Lavanya, 29, and Subbalaxmi, 31, arrived on the scene to play just about every genre ‚Äî from jazz to Carnatic, and fusion to Bollywood. 

At the recent Chennai music season, Lavanya and her alto sax drew curious crowds. She is young, petite, dressed unusually glamorously for the Carnatic stage and totally unselfconscious about the effect she is creating. She sits cross-legged on the stage, a totally un-sax position, and starts playing like one would the nagaswaram or the shehnai. Her music is vigorous, fast and it doesn't take the audience long to burst into applause every once in a while. She tells you later that she would prefer a leisurely exploration of music, not this frenzied brilliance. "But I am told that this is what everyone wants," she says in cheerful exasperation. 

The saxophone has already made inroads into Carnatic music thanks to the pioneering work of their guru Kadri Gopalnath, but it still isn't easy coaxing the instrument to cough up gamakas (glides). "It is tough but once I start playing, I am only bothered about perfection. You need a lot of strength and energy to play the sax ‚Äî juggling fingering, blowing, balancing ‚Äî there is no time to worry about what anyone says or thinks," says Lavanya, who is playing alone this time as sister Subbalaxmi is stuck with an assignment in Mumbai.
